description: From Middle English bable, babel, babull, babulle, from Old French babel, baubel (“trinket, child's toy”), most likely a reduplication of bel, ultimately from Latin bellus (“pretty”).

entries.meaning: A cheap showy ornament piece of jewellery; a gewgaw.
(figurative, by extension) Anything trivial and worthless.
examples: His hind quarters were likewise short, and not racinglike, and taken as a specimen of the horse, he was a mere bauble when looked at by the side of an English race-horse, much less a hunter.

entries.meaning: A small shiny spherical decoration, commonly put on Christmas trees.
A club or sceptre carried by a jester.
